qas.question: There are no IPA symbols for what?
What may be doubled to indicate a long aspiration?
What language, according to the text, may need double stops to indicate aspiration length?
How are voice-onset time details usually presented?
Which two IPA symbols are marked?
The two degrees of aspiration in English stops are transcribed as what?
The details of voice-onset symbols are given how?
Which old letter for light aspiration is now obsolete?
The aspiration modifier letter may be tripled to indicate what?

context: There are no dedicated IPA symbols for <a0_0>degrees of aspiration<a0_0/> and typically only two degrees are marked: <b4_0>unaspirated ⟨k⟩ and aspirated ⟨kʰ⟩<b4_0/>. An old symbol for light aspiration was <b7_0>⟨ʻ⟩<b7_0/>, but this is now obsolete. The <a1_0>aspiration modifier<a1_0/> letter may be doubled to indicate <b8_0>especially strong or long aspiration<b8_0/>. Hence, the two degrees of aspiration in <a2_0>Korean<a2_0/> stops are sometimes transcribed <b5_0>⟨kʰ kʰʰ⟩ or ⟨kʻ⟩ and ⟨kʰ⟩<b5_0/>, but they are usually transcribed [k] and [kʰ], with the details of voice-onset time given <a3_0><b6_0>numerically<b6_0/><a3_0/>.
